comment.body: Long story short: people are lazy to think (i've no idea whether it's due to the way how brain biologically works or just a cultural phenomenon) and are afraid of uncertainty. This leads to a strong desire to build a comfortable view of the world and sustain it at all costs, and thus to not accepting any "blasphemy" and trying to interpret everything (including communication) in an easy way. To a certain degree, even this very answer is an illustration to what i'm talking about (see how i build The Theory of Human Stupidity, which makes it easy to interpret any stupidity and let my brain relax and not think).

Yeah, obscure networks and obscure content can help each other ;) [Uploaded a music vid](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1517014178_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE), lets see how well this goes
@styromaniac@zeroid.bit: weird, it says 1/1 peers for me. maybe tor issue?
@styromaniac@zeroid.bit: hmm, i see. is there any easy way to bridge, except for running two nodes?
@styromaniac@zeroid.bit: eh, i suppose i'll have to dig deeper into 0net to share my content..

>it's so < 2015 though X)

Lol, this is the reason i'm 'still' using jquery (despite hating the guts of "$" everywhere); when i tried to find what should i use, i saw too much choice (and unnecessary setup) to bother even starting (though i'd probably pick some FP lang for more serious webdev).

@Binchan: i've no idea what is trending in webdev (apart from creating dozens new libs and langs), but i hope someone managed to produce at least one decent FP platform for web. Of course, it's possible to use FP practices even in non-pure environment (like lambdas, generators in python), but if starting something new and of medium size i'd try to go full FP road. I like FP ever since i learned about it and even more so after i learned haskell, but unfortunately i don't find many opportunities to code in pure fp langs, because of libs&performance issues
You certainly deserve a "0net archivarius" title ^_^
duplicate?

There are enough languages for every word to sound funny in one of them. Using alternative lexicon is really just a community-building exercise, which might work better or worse, but in this case attempts to promote 0net.

On the other hand, calling *all* sites (or zites for that matter) "apps" is obviously incorrect. (And stylistically i got to agree that "zapps" is not a good idea (though that is again a taste matter))

Depending on the perspective, one might say that internet is not as heavily censored in china since we can still read them. Chinese firewall supposedly has content analysis, but apparently it is not all that advanced (or else they decided that 0net is fine at this point, who knows).

>when all colleagues, relatives and friends receive video record of it- it is awful for u.

I wonder when everybody will realize that it's less awful than supporting such blackmailers (even when they do not bluff).
Hmm? ~~How should it look? What's different?~~ Do you mean italic cyrillics looking different?

@Binchan: ah, yeah, i was wrong about chotto, for some reason i thought it has voiced sound. But "у" shouldn't be used in russian (though some other cyrillic-based languages have different pronunciation) transcription for romaji "w"; first of all, it wouldn't be read as diphthong, because russian doesn't have diphthongs starting with u. And secondly, it would introduce ambiguity between うあ (уа/ua) and わ/は (ва/wa).
"дж" is the best approximation of "j", though some russian japanese transcription systems use "дз" (dz) instead for consonant in じ.

Hearing "hard vowel" about [iotated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iotation) ones is kinda painful. Usually the sound they make in syllables (when "й" (i/j/y) sound is not pronounced) is described as being "softer". Anyway, in russian there would be no official difference between чо and чё or джо/джё. But i still have my tastes ;) because there's theoretical difference following from other pronunciation rules.

Yet another difference is that you used "з" (z) instead of either "э" or "е".

Japanese is said to be [SOV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject–object–verb) language and also [topic-prominent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic-prominent_language) and honestly i don't find its grammar to be exceptionally hard or something. More like, i find it fun.

I guess that diagram/article is good for remembering particles; i should probably try to systematize my understanding of them at some point.

I also agree that 한글 is one of the most logical writing systems in use (similar sounds are written similarly) and no wonder since it was more crafted than evolved. Still, there seem to a little confusion with ㅐ/ㅔ and compound vowels with similar/identical sounds. Also, it is heavily rooted in korean pronunciation, which makes it harder to apply to different languages.

Hmm, after actually reading that article i started to wonder "why not analyse those particles as part of grammatical case system?" and sure enough japanese [is listed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_case#Japanese) on wikipedia's page on cases.

@Binchan: yeah, punctuation is quite a late addition; some ancient phonetic scripts also didn't have vwls.

Incidentally, original lojban orthography doesn't have punctuation (except for sometimes elideable spaces and glottal-stop marks), because all of semantic punctuation is actually pronounced.

>using yes no, much little, etc as a word, exclamation mark used a word instead

I wonder whether they've actually read it as is ;)
I wish i could properly distinguish between ㅓ, ㅗ and ㅜ (and their iotated variations) in real speech.. but then one can say i'm just lazy and don't really try to learn korean.

@Leftside: i've heard recordings, which are demonstrating better than english samples.. i can probably distinguish them when they're isolated, but not in real fast speech.


@Binchan: i see ;) 한글 sure has a nice balance between looking exotic and being easy to learn.
@Leftside: yeah, either that or listen way too much of real speech ;) better yet, dive into speaking community
@Binchan: IPA might be good (though still not ideal) for transcribing specific sound, but it doesn't give a way to show spectre of allowed sounds, unless you write them all down.

Nah, it's not C# or C++++, it's C♯ ^_^

Although i've no idea what interpretation came first.

Nice. And there i wanted to complain that you've made other 0net zites look plain and boring ;)

Unfortunately, i can't be bothered to apply all the nice-looking custom styles just yet.
@Binchan: nah, i meant "plain and boring *in comparison with your blog*" ;) After looking at your site for too long, switching to 0me makes my eyes feel almost slipping on the plain bg.

Well, at least it shows you what it is on "copy link" ;) One can easily have "links" that supposedly lead to one place, but clicking them will lead you to another. And you'll never know until you click it or read the code.

@Binchan: it's not even the problem of js (language) per se, it's rather that browsers implement all sorts of apis that should really be optional and customisable by user. But today's mainstream browsers are made by non-[hackers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hacker_culture) for non-hackers.

As i see it, it's an instance of a bigger issue: lack of communication between technical and "non-technically creative" people in 0net and many libre software communities in general (although sometimes it's plain lack of the latter kind of people in such communities). Which *can* be solved if everyone starts to be creative in all ways possible, but perhaps easier solution would be to fill that communicational gap.
@Styromaniac: have you tried Krita? Not sure what your needs are, but generally it is more friendly (than Gimp) at least for drawing purposes (not sure about photo-processing capabilities though).

>I also don't want someone to be able to claim a modified version as proprietary

For copyleft code license, the only reasonable choice is *GPL family. The way copyright laws and copyleft strategy work, it doesn't make sense to create competing incompatible licenses. Technically, there are a couple of other copyleft licenses that are compatible with gpl, but the possible benefits of using them are likely to be outweighted by their obscurity and possible confusions.

There is one other notable copyleft license, which has valid usecases: CC-BY-SA. From 4.0 version, it's one-way compatible to GPL, although it generally isn't meant for code and it does not protect source code (so people can make closed-source derivatives, even if they still have to be licensed under CC-BY-SA).

>Some of you don't like GPL

People who don't like GPL tend to also not like copyleft in general ;)

>Do people ever put their projects under Public Domain?

Some people do. In general, it might be better to use CC0 or similar in order to ensure compatibility with copyright laws in various countries.

>I know I could draft my own license

That's a path to obscurity. Makes it harder for people to understand whether they can use your code and on what conditions. Also, copyleft licenses are generally incompatible with each other, unless specifically made so.


My personal preferences of licenses is

- GPLv3+ for most code (possibly v2+ if there are essential compatibility issues; possibly LGPL, although i don't think i'd ever use it myself; then there is also AGPL, but i feel that full compatibility with GPL code is usually more important)

- CC-BY-SA for works of art and other non-code content (although i may consider GPL if said work uses a lot of code for its final form generation)

- PD/CC0 for its ultimate anti-copyright spirit or for convenience

- Apache 2.0 for a "lax" non-copyleft license (compared to other such licenses, it offers some protection against patent abuse), although i'd never use it myself anyway (tbh, i don't see much point in this middle option between copyleft and public domain)

>everyone assumes they don't have permission by default to do anything with it

You're forgetting about "fair use", which allows doing "something" without any permissions.

>I could sue anyone who photocopies my paintings without my permission while the copyright stands

Dunno how it works in US, but in some cases it's not the act of copying that is prohibited, but the act of then sharing such copies.
I haven't been following how blacklists work, but why not simply use links' hashes instead of links themselves, if sharing links is a concern?

As far as i understand (haven't read the code though), current 0mail has recipients encrypted as well. So you need to run the decrypting code on every zite update in order to receive updates in real time.

But then even if there would be a way to do that, 0mail has a scaling issue, which might be easier to solve with a different paradigm (rather than patching current one).

>Take a shower or bath, don't dry yourself off, get dressed and go outside.

>An alternative solution is to soak your clothes right before putting them on.

Better yet, bathe in your clothes ;)

One reason not to use ids in css is separation of concerns. Id == "unique element", but for styling purposes that's usually irrelevant. That's not to mention the obvious "what if you decide to have another similar element later"

..but that thought is already present on page you're referring

I think the point is pretty clear: if you live in certain jurisdictions, don't take hiding your identity seriously and clicked on that image, you may already be in danger. And this can be addressed both to 0net users and authorities.

Whether this point is worth making in such a manner is another question.

>If you fear you've messed something up, if your site has peers, you can delete required files if the older versions were published, and the rest might be backed up on proxies

>I can delete those files, clear the browser cache, then revisit the site to revert to the last published changes

You should really use [VCS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_control_system) for any kind of (even just a bit) serious development.

The problem is that desire to belong to a group is very strong in humans. Race (gender, language, age, etc) is an easy way to divide humanity into groups. Not only it's easy in itself, it's also supported by most existing societies. Then, once you associate yourself with the group, you have to share its perceived actions/beliefs/ideals. Which may lead to genocide or feeling shame for others from your group doing it, depending on other factors. Or to desiring diversity for the sake of diversity.

Back to your question,

>Who thinks white guilt/shame is felt by anyone but SJWs who are being racist against themselves?

I don't enjoy terminology you employ, but if by SJWs you mean people who are actively "fighting" for a cause, you're probably wrong. Racism is so ubiquitous that i'm pretty sure there are people who merely sympathize with "restoring racial justice" (and thus feel some of that white guilt) without actively fighting for it.
@Styromaniac: wait, did i speak of any good causes?

Do you think all SJWs have a good cause or what? Besides, you were first to bring them up as those who supposedly feel white shame.

..i should probably have refrained from going into discussion without clear understanding of exact meaning of your words.

Anyway, my point is pretty much that most people are racist, although in different ways and proportions. Some are fighting "for their race", some are fighting "against race discrimination", etc, but most do not fight for anything and simply cling to their racist worldview.

There are of course people who are fighting against race discrimination without being racist themselves, but from what i can observe, they are in minority.

Oh, and another point. Racist people can do good things out of their racist ideas (such as fighting worse kind of racism, for example). But the word is so loaded with negative that people don't like calling whoever they perceive as doing good "racist". People generally don't like it when good outcome is brought by bad ideas, they much prefer black&white world

>You'll have to see this polarization on clearnet video sharing sites

Thanks, but i'll pass. I'm depressed about lack of wisdom in humanity enough already ;)

>Maybe it's not the best strategy if they ever had a shred of the correct definition in mind, but usually I don't see that the way people have been going. How do I do better?

I don't see an easy solution. Personally i prefer to talk to generally sensible people who might have some bad or incorrect views. It's already hard enough to fight deeply ingrained prejudices in otherwise kind and intelligent people. Trying to communicate with people who you don't have much in common is much harder.

It also doesn't help that getting rid of prejudices doesn't make one's life less miserable. The emotions which fuel extremists will not disappear and they'll have to deal with them anyway (and you want to take their method of dealing away — that's another reason for unconscious resistance)

You can change 0me nick at any time in your profile settings; to create a "new user", you need to register another id (on an id provider that is supported by the hub you want to use) and then switch to that id here (can be done in the 0-button sidebar on the right)

As far as i'm concerned, things or ideas (pictures, algorithms) cannot be ethical/unethical. Ethics only apply to humans (and their acts), but even then act of creating such a program by itself isn't something that can be measured on ethics scale. Reasons to ban non-child-harming CP (either as what you describe, or more real cases of own nude teen photos) are (to the best of my knowledge) no more convincing than those to ban depictions of violence in games or movies. That is to say, i can easily see potential good and bad consequences, but i don't have enough data to give universal convincing prediction as to which would outweigh the other. But that was about ban laws, not ethics. From ethical standpoint, distributing pieces of legally (non-violently, not intruding on privacy etc) obtained bits to people who wish to receive them shouldn't be labeled as bad per se. If you have reasons to believe it would lead to crime, only then it will be unethical

Even if it does something bad, you can't really deny ability people to share blocklists. Even if there wouldn't be a built-in for it in 0net, there is no ethical way to stop people from developing and using it

I think you don't understand what PD means. It's not a license and if you dedicate something to public domain, you can't place any restrictions

Unless you're using PD in some other vague sense, in which case i'd recommend choosing more appropriate term or at least explain what you mean

@Styromaniac: i'm not a fan of making new licenses in general; beside any additional legal ambiguities, your particular wording seem to not allow any combination with other works (and possibly even force to transfer copyright of any modification to you? no idea)

@Styromaniac: i would recommend choosing GPL (or one of its variations) if you want to stop others from distributing your code (possibly with modifications, possibly as part of combined work) without giving their source modifications

@Styromaniac: not sure i understand what you mean by "owning" here. From copyright perspective, one's own code is by default owned by its creator; combined work will not be owned by any single entity, but for it to even be legal parties should agree on common terms

If by ownership you mean being able to distribute combined/modified work on different terms, than you can simply choose copyleft license. But there's a caveat with those: unless made explicitly compatible, works under different (even if their meaning is pretty much the same) licenses cannot be combined. That's why if you want copyleft, it's best to choose GPL (or, again, its variations, depending on what you want)
Might not matter in this case, but using custom license is a road to isolation
You probably shouldn't limit that to newcomers. Information isn't spreading magically here, so i bet most people around haven't seen those
